title: GM's (GM) Work Shift Cut in Michigan Is Sign of Waning Demand for Small Cars - TheStreet
text:
Reddit Email Print Reprint General Motors   ( GM - Get Report )  , on the heels of a strong third quarter, said on Friday it was cutting one of two work shifts at its Orion Township, Mich., assembly plant that builds small Chevrolet and Buick cars. 
The move reflects weak demand for the vehicles and a waning preference of American consumers for small, fuel-efficient cars. The layoff will affect 400 to 500 workers, many of whom are eligible for transfer to other GM plants. The reduction in workforce is a disappointment to the United Auto Workers union, which is trying to expand its membership. 
The UAW said on Thursday it is starting talks with GM on a new four-year labor contract, following ratification of a pact Thursday by hourly workers at Fiat Chrysler .

During the government-sponsored reorganization of GM and Chrysler following their 2009 bankruptcies, the Obama administration signaled its strong support for the manufacture of small, fuel-efficient cars in the U.S.  rather than importing them from Mexico or farther away , a strategy that had been more attractive for automakers from a cost and profitability standpoint. 
President Obama visited GM Orion Township with South Korean President Lee Myung-bak in 2011 to highlight small-car production at the plant. 
In January, GM said it will begin building a new small battery-powered car, the Chevrolet Bolt, at the Orion Township plant. 
Chevrolet Sonic, Chevrolet Spark and Buick Verano higher-mileage small cars built at Orion Township were GM's answer to small imports like the Honda Fit, Toyota Corolla and Nissan Versa. But the entire segment has been struggling, especially in light of the collapse of oil prices that has driven the average price of a gallon of regular unleaded gasoline to $2.26 a gallon, down from $2.80 a gallon in June and nearly $4 a gallon in 2012. 
Consumer preference notwithstanding, regulators worldwide are tightening fuel-efficiency standards. Though U.S. auto industry sales have risen 5% through September and are on track for one of the industry's best years ever, demand for small cars as well as electrics and gas-electric hybrids is tepid. According to Kelley Blue Book, the subcompact car segment declined 1.4% through September, electrics were off 18.1% and gas-electric hybrids dropped 15.9% from a year earlier. 
Meantime, higher-profit Chevrolet and GMC large pickups and SUVs have been selling strongly. GM shares this week rose 7.3%, compared to a Dow Jones Industrial Average that was up 2.2%, on the strength of a third-quarter financial statement that reported a record quarterly $3.3 billion operating profit in North America . GM's net income for the quarter fell slightly due to the cost of recalls.
